title: 7 Books To Read Before Their Movie Adaptations Hit The Big Screen This Year
text:
facebook 
Book to screen adaptations are our way of obsessing over books long after we've read the last pages. While it might look silly (to some) to take your Harry Potter book to bed each night and pray that Sirius Black doesn't die this time around, movies are the sane way of keeping that craziness alive. All you need to do is hit rewind and watch your favourite characters come to life, over and over again. Last year we had gems like The Girl On The Train and The Jungle Book that managed to stay true to essences of those tomes (and didn't have us jumping out of our seats screaming ‘that's not how it happened in the books' too many times). This year too we have some great adaptations to look forward to and we suggest putting them on the TBR (to be read) list right away so that you are better prepared to watch the film. 1. Fifty Shades: Darker by E. L. James 
The first movie in the series, Fifty Shades of Grey , created quite a storm and the second movie promises to be as steamy as the sequel. Set in Paris and Vancouver the movie takes off from Anastasia Steele trying to move on from her relationship with Christian Grey. 
Release date: February, 2017 
Buy the book here 2. The Dark Tower: The Gunslinger by Stephen King 
The first book in the "Dark Tower" series, The Gunslinger is considered to be Stephen King's magnum opus. Stringing together five short stories, the plot revolves around Roland Deschain, the last gunslinger in the Old West (trigger-happy, testosterone-fuelled men in the American Old West) who has been chasing his adversary for several years now. The movie promises to be a fresh new take on the 1978 novel and we sure are excited to watch Idris Elba, Matthew McConaughey and Tom Taylor spin their magic on screen. 
Release date: June, 2017 
Buy the book here 3. Murder On The Orient Express by Agatha Christie 
Featuring Belgian detective Hercule Poirot, this cult book was first published in 1934 and follows the story of Hercule who is caught up with solving a murder committed on the train he is travelling in. One passenger lies dead in his compartment, stabbed a dozen times, his door locked from the inside. 
Release date: November, 2017 
Buy the book here 4. Before I Fall by Lauren Oliver 
Before I Fall follows the story of 17-year-old Samantha Kingston who is killed in a car accident. She clearly remembers dying however the following day, she wakes up in bed, alive once again. For some strange reason she is fated to relive that day, over and over again, until she sets things right. The movie is set to premier at the Sundance Film Festival this month before its theatre releases. 
Release date: March, 2017 
Buy the book here 5. The Zookeeper's Wife by Diane Ackerman 
This non-fictional book based on the unpublished diary of Antonina Żabińska, is the story of Antonina and her husband, both zookeepers who save the lives of 300 Jews who were imprisoned during Germany's invasion of Poland. 
Release date: March 31, 2017 
Buy the book here 6. The Circle by David Eggers 
Mae Holland, a recent college graduate lands a job atThe Circle, which is a powerful tech company run by the so-called "Three Wise Men". Mae starts out small but she quickly climbs the corporate ladder. The movie stars Emma Watson and Tom Hanks. 
Release date: April 28, 2017 
Buy the book here 7. Let It Snow by John Green, Maureen Johnson and Lauren Myracle 
The compilation novel consist of three separate stories - The Jubilee Express by Maureen Johnson, A Cheertastic Christmas Miracle by John Green and The Patron Saint of Pigs by Lauren Myracle - follows the story of three teenagers as they experience a huge snow storm in town during Christmas Eve. 
Release date: November, 2017
